trans-unit.source: How to use Service Bus queues (Ruby) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Service Bus queues (Ruby) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Service Bus queues in Azure. Code samples written in Ruby.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Service Bus queues in Azure. Code samples written in Ruby.

trans-unit.source: This guide will show you how to use Service Bus queues.
trans-unit.target: This guide will show you how to use Service Bus queues.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in Ruby and use the Azure gem.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in Ruby and use the Azure gem.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include creating queues, sending and receiving messages, and deleting queues.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include creating queues, sending and receiving messages, and deleting queues.

trans-unit.source: For more information on queues, see the <linkText>Next Steps</linkText><title></title> section.
trans-unit.target: For more information on queues, see the <linkText>Next Steps</linkText><title></title> section.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus Queues support a brokered messaging communication model.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus Queues support a brokered messaging communication model.

trans-unit.source: When using queues, components of a distributed application do not communicate directly with each other, they instead exchange messages via a queue, which acts as an intermediary.
trans-unit.target: When using queues, components of a distributed application do not communicate directly with each other, they instead exchange messages via a queue, which acts as an intermediary.

trans-unit.source: A message producer (sender) hands off a message to the queue and then continues its processing.
trans-unit.target: A message producer (sender) hands off a message to the queue and then continues its processing.

trans-unit.source: Asynchronously, a message consumer (receiver) pulls the message from the queue and processes it.
trans-unit.target: Asynchronously, a message consumer (receiver) pulls the message from the queue and processes it.

trans-unit.source: The producer does not have to wait for a reply from the consumer in order to continue to process and send further messages.
trans-unit.target: The producer does not have to wait for a reply from the consumer in order to continue to process and send further messages.

trans-unit.source: Queues offer First In, First Out (FIFO) message delivery to one or more competing consumers.
trans-unit.target: Queues offer First In, First Out (FIFO) message delivery to one or more competing consumers.

trans-unit.source: That is, messages are typically received and processed by the receivers in the order in which they were added to the queue, and each message is received and processed by only one message consumer.
trans-unit.target: That is, messages are typically received and processed by the receivers in the order in which they were added to the queue, and each message is received and processed by only one message consumer.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>QueueConcepts</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>QueueConcepts</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Service Bus queues are a general-purpose technology that can be used for a wide variety of scenarios:
trans-unit.target: Service Bus queues are a general-purpose technology that can be used for a wide variety of scenarios:

trans-unit.source: Communication between web and worker roles in a multi-tier Azure application
trans-unit.target: Communication between web and worker roles in a multi-tier Azure application

trans-unit.source: Communication between on-premises apps and Azure hosted apps in a hybrid solution
trans-unit.target: Communication between on-premises apps and Azure hosted apps in a hybrid solution

trans-unit.source: Communication between components of a distributed application running on-premises in different organizations or departments of an organization
trans-unit.target: Communication between components of a distributed application running on-premises in different organizations or departments of an organization

trans-unit.source: Using queues can enable you to scale out your applications better, and enable more resiliency to your architecture.
trans-unit.target: Using queues can enable you to scale out your applications better, and enable more resiliency to your architecture.

trans-unit.source: To begin using Service Bus queues in Azure, you must first create a service namespace.
trans-unit.target: To begin using Service Bus queues in Azure, you must first create a service namespace.

trans-unit.source: A service namespace provides a scoping container for addressing Service Bus resources within your application.
trans-unit.target: A service namespace provides a scoping container for addressing Service Bus resources within your application.

trans-unit.source: You must create the namespace through the command-line interface because the Portal does not create the service bus with an ACS connection.
trans-unit.target: You must create the namespace through the command-line interface because the Portal does not create the service bus with an ACS connection.

trans-unit.source: To create a service namespace:
trans-unit.target: To create a service namespace:

trans-unit.source: Open an Azure Powershell console.
trans-unit.target: Open an Azure Powershell console.

trans-unit.source: Type the command to create an Azure service bus namespace as shown below.
trans-unit.target: Type the command to create an Azure service bus namespace as shown below.

trans-unit.source: Provide your own namespace value and specify the same region as your application.
trans-unit.target: Provide your own namespace value and specify the same region as your application.

trans-unit.source: New-AzureSBNamespace -Name 'yourexamplenamespace' -Location 'West US' -NamespaceType 'Messaging' -CreateACSNamespace $true
trans-unit.target: New-AzureSBNamespace -Name 'yourexamplenamespace' -Location 'West US' -NamespaceType 'Messaging' -CreateACSNamespace $true

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create Namespace</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create Namespace</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In order to perform management operations, such as creating a queue on the new namespace, you must obtain the management credentials for the namespace.
trans-unit.target: In order to perform management operations, such as creating a queue on the new namespace, you must obtain the management credentials for the namespace.

trans-unit.source: The PowerShell cmdlet you ran to create the Azure service bus namespace displays the key you can use to manage the namespace.
trans-unit.target: The PowerShell cmdlet you ran to create the Azure service bus namespace displays the key you can use to manage the namespace.

trans-unit.source: Copy the DefaultKey value.
trans-unit.target: Copy the DefaultKey value.

trans-unit.source: You will use this value in your code later in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: You will use this value in your code later in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Copy key</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Copy key</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can also find this key if you log on to the <linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title> and navigate to the connection information for your service bus namespace.
trans-unit.target: You can also find this key if you log on to the <linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title> and navigate to the connection information for your service bus namespace.

trans-unit.source: Create a Ruby application.
trans-unit.target: Create a Ruby application.

trans-unit.source: For instructions, see <linkText>Create a Ruby Application on Azure</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions, see <linkText>Create a Ruby Application on Azure</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To use Azure service bus, you need to download and use the Ruby azure package, which includes a set of convenience libraries that communicate with the storage REST services.
trans-unit.target: To use Azure service bus, you need to download and use the Ruby azure package, which includes a set of convenience libraries that communicate with the storage REST services.

trans-unit.source: Use a command-line interface such as PowerShell (Windows), Terminal (Mac), or Bash (Unix).
trans-unit.target: Use a command-line interface such as PowerShell (Windows), Terminal (Mac), or Bash (Unix).

trans-unit.source: Type "gem install azure" in the command window to install the gem and dependencies.
trans-unit.target: Type "gem install azure" in the command window to install the gem and dependencies.

trans-unit.source: Use your favorite text editor, add the following to the top of the Ruby file where you intend to use storage:
trans-unit.target: Use your favorite text editor, add the following to the top of the Ruby file where you intend to use storage:

trans-unit.source: The azure module will read the environment variables AZURE\_SERVICEBUS\_NAMESPACE and AZURE\_SERVICEBUS\_ACCESS_KEY for information required to connect to your Azure service bus namespace.
trans-unit.target: The azure module will read the environment variables AZURE\_SERVICEBUS\_NAMESPACE and AZURE\_SERVICEBUS\_ACCESS_KEY for information required to connect to your Azure service bus namespace.

trans-unit.source: If these environment variables are not set, you must specify the namespace information before using Azure::ServiceBusService with the following code:
trans-unit.target: If these environment variables are not set, you must specify the namespace information before using Azure::ServiceBusService with the following code:

trans-unit.source: Set the service bus namespace value to the value you created rather than the entire URL.
trans-unit.target: Set the service bus namespace value to the value you created rather than the entire URL.

trans-unit.source: For example, use "yourexamplenamespace", not "yourexamplenamespace.servicebus.windows.net".
trans-unit.target: For example, use "yourexamplenamespace", not "yourexamplenamespace.servicebus.windows.net".

trans-unit.source: The Azure::ServiceBusService object lets you work with queues.
trans-unit.target: The Azure::ServiceBusService object lets you work with queues.

trans-unit.source: To create a queue, use the create_queue() method.
trans-unit.target: To create a queue, use the create_queue() method.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a queue or print out the error if there is any.
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a queue or print out the error if there is any.

trans-unit.source: You can also pass in a Azure::ServiceBus::Queue object with additional options, which allows you to override default queue settings such as message time to live or maximum queue size.
trans-unit.target: You can also pass in a Azure::ServiceBus::Queue object with additional options, which allows you to override default queue settings such as message time to live or maximum queue size.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows setting the maximum queue size to 5GB and time to live to 1 minute:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows setting the maximum queue size to 5GB and time to live to 1 minute:

trans-unit.source: To send a message to a Service Bus queue, you application will call the send\_queue\_message() method on the Azure::ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: To send a message to a Service Bus queue, you application will call the send\_queue\_message() method on the Azure::ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: Messages sent to (and received from) service bus queues are Azure::ServiceBus::BrokeredMessage objects, and have a set of standard properties (such as label and time\_to\_live), a dictionary that is used to hold custom application specific properties, and a body of arbitrary application data.
trans-unit.target: Messages sent to (and received from) service bus queues are Azure::ServiceBus::BrokeredMessage objects, and have a set of standard properties (such as label and time\_to\_live), a dictionary that is used to hold custom application specific properties, and a body of arbitrary application data.

trans-unit.source: An application can set the body of the message by passing a string value as the message and any required standard properties will be populated with default values.
trans-unit.target: An application can set the body of the message by passing a string value as the message and any required standard properties will be populated with default values.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates how to send a test message to the queue named "test-queue" using send\_queue\_message():
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates how to send a test message to the queue named "test-queue" using send\_queue\_message():

trans-unit.source: Service bus queues support a maximum message size of 256 KB (the header, which includes the standard and custom application properties, can have a maximum size of 64 KB).
trans-unit.target: Service bus queues support a maximum message size of 256 KB (the header, which includes the standard and custom application properties, can have a maximum size of 64 KB).

trans-unit.source: There is no limit on the number of messages held in a queue but there is a cap on the total size of the messages held by a queue.
trans-unit.target: There is no limit on the number of messages held in a queue but there is a cap on the total size of the messages held by a queue.

trans-unit.source: This queue size is defined at creation time, with an upper limit of 5 GB.
trans-unit.target: This queue size is defined at creation time, with an upper limit of 5 GB.

trans-unit.source: Messages are received from a queue using the receive\_queue\_message() method on the Azure::ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: Messages are received from a queue using the receive\_queue\_message() method on the Azure::ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: By default, messages are read and locked without being deleted from the queue.
trans-unit.target: By default, messages are read and locked without being deleted from the queue.

trans-unit.source: However, you can delete messages from the queue as they are read by setting the :peek_lock option to false.
trans-unit.target: However, you can delete messages from the queue as they are read by setting the :peek_lock option to false.

trans-unit.source: The default behavior makes the reading and deleting into a two stage operation, which makes it possible to support applications that cannot tolerate missing messages.
trans-unit.target: The default behavior makes the reading and deleting into a two stage operation, which makes it possible to support applications that cannot tolerate missing messages.

trans-unit.source: When service bus receives a request, it finds the next message to be consumed, locks it to prevent other consumers receiving it, and then returns it to the application.
trans-unit.target: When service bus receives a request, it finds the next message to be consumed, locks it to prevent other consumers receiving it, and then returns it to the application.

trans-unit.source: After the application finishes processing the message (or stores it reliably for future processing), it completes the second stage of the receive process by calling delete\_queue\_message() method and providing the message to be deleted as a parameter.
trans-unit.target: After the application finishes processing the message (or stores it reliably for future processing), it completes the second stage of the receive process by calling delete\_queue\_message() method and providing the message to be deleted as a parameter.

trans-unit.source: The delete\_queue\_message() method will mark the message as being consumed and remove it from the queue.
trans-unit.target: The delete\_queue\_message() method will mark the message as being consumed and remove it from the queue.

trans-unit.source: If the :peek\_lock parameter is set to false, reading and deleting the message becomes the simplest model, and works best for scenarios in which an application can tolerate not processing a message in the event of a failure.
trans-unit.target: If the :peek\_lock parameter is set to false, reading and deleting the message becomes the simplest model, and works best for scenarios in which an application can tolerate not processing a message in the event of a failure.

trans-unit.source: To understand this, consider a scenario in which the consumer issues the receive request and then crashes before processing it.
trans-unit.target: To understand this, consider a scenario in which the consumer issues the receive request and then crashes before processing it.

trans-unit.source: Because Service Bus will have marked the message as being consumed, then when the application restarts and begins consuming messages again, it will have missed the message that was consumed prior to the crash.
trans-unit.target: Because Service Bus will have marked the message as being consumed, then when the application restarts and begins consuming messages again, it will have missed the message that was consumed prior to the crash.

trans-unit.source: The example below demonstrates how messages can be received and processed using receive\_queue\_message().
trans-unit.target: The example below demonstrates how messages can be received and processed using receive\_queue\_message().

trans-unit.source: The example first receives and deletes a message by using :peek\_lock set to false, then it receives another message and then deletes the message using delete\_queue\_message():
trans-unit.target: The example first receives and deletes a message by using :peek\_lock set to false, then it receives another message and then deletes the message using delete\_queue\_message():

trans-unit.source: Service bus provides functionality to help you gracefully recover from errors in your application or difficulties processing a message.
trans-unit.target: Service bus provides functionality to help you gracefully recover from errors in your application or difficulties processing a message.

trans-unit.source: If a receiver application is unable to process the message for some reason, then it can call the unlock\_queue\_message() method on the Azure::ServiceBusService object.
trans-unit.target: If a receiver application is unable to process the message for some reason, then it can call the unlock\_queue\_message() method on the Azure::ServiceBusService object.

trans-unit.source: This will cause service bus to unlock the message within the queue and make it available to be received again, either by the same consuming application or by another consuming application.
trans-unit.target: This will cause service bus to unlock the message within the queue and make it available to be received again, either by the same consuming application or by another consuming application.

trans-unit.source: There is also a timeout associated with a message locked within the queue, and if the application fails to process the message before the lock timeout expires (e.g., if the application crashes), then service bus will unlock the message automatically and make it available to be received again.
trans-unit.target: There is also a timeout associated with a message locked within the queue, and if the application fails to process the message before the lock timeout expires (e.g., if the application crashes), then service bus will unlock the message automatically and make it available to be received again.

trans-unit.source: In the event that the application crashes after processing the message but before the delete\_queue\_message() method is called, then the message will be redelivered to the application when it restarts.
trans-unit.target: In the event that the application crashes after processing the message but before the delete\_queue\_message() method is called, then the message will be redelivered to the application when it restarts.

trans-unit.source: This is often called At Least Once Processing, that is, each message will be processed at least once but in certain situations the same message may be redelivered.
trans-unit.target: This is often called At Least Once Processing, that is, each message will be processed at least once but in certain situations the same message may be redelivered.

trans-unit.source: If the scenario cannot tolerate duplicate processing, then application developers should add additional logic to their application to handle duplicate message delivery.
trans-unit.target: If the scenario cannot tolerate duplicate processing, then application developers should add additional logic to their application to handle duplicate message delivery.

trans-unit.source: This is often achieved using the message\_id property of the message, which will remain constant across delivery attempts.
trans-unit.target: This is often achieved using the message\_id property of the message, which will remain constant across delivery attempts.

trans-unit.source: Now that you've learned the basics of Service Bus queues, follow these links to learn more.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've learned the basics of Service Bus queues, follow these links to learn more.

trans-unit.source: See the MSDN Reference: <linkText>Queues, Topics, and Subscriptions</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: See the MSDN Reference: <linkText>Queues, Topics, and Subscriptions</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Visit the <linkText>Azure SDK for Ruby</linkText><title></title> repository on GitHub
trans-unit.target: Visit the <linkText>Azure SDK for Ruby</linkText><title></title> repository on GitHub

trans-unit.source: For a comparision between the Azure Service Bus Queues discussed in this article and Azure Queues discussed in the <linkText>How to use the Azure Queue Service</linkText><title></title> article, see <linkText>Azure Queues and Azure Service Bus Queues - Compared and Contrasted</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For a comparision between the Azure Service Bus Queues discussed in this article and Azure Queues discussed in the <linkText>How to use the Azure Queue Service</linkText><title></title> article, see <linkText>Azure Queues and Azure Service Bus Queues - Compared and Contrasted</linkText><title></title>
